Issues.Title: IVY Error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of AppModule
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package ngcc ### Is this a regression? Yes, it works at 9.0.0 ### Description It actually works in the end. I think it is caused by the order of the ngcc compilation. The problem is like when I have a package A using another package B. During ngcc compilation, somehow package A runs before package B. And it throws an error. However, once package B got compiled, it will compile package A again and it will work. And the build will work as well. I think it is a bug that it compiles out of order. It should compiles base on the dependency list. The good thing is it actually fixes itself in the end. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I can't reproduce in a small example yet. ## üî• Exception or Error 

Compiling @m*****b/ngm-image-gallery : es2015 as esm2015
**Compiling @m*****b/ngm-image-gallery : es2015 as esm2015**

node_modules/@m*****b/ng-helper/components/confirm-button/confirm-button.module.d.ts:1:22 - error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of NgmImageGalleryModule, but could not be resolved to an NgModule class.

This likely means that the library (@m*****b/ng-helper/components/confirm-button) which declares NgmConfirmButtonModule has not been processed correctly by ngcc, or is not compatible with Angular Ivy. Check if a newer version of the library is available, and update if so. Also consider checking with the library's authors to see if the library is expected to be compatible with Ivy.

This likely means that the library (@m*****b/ng-helper/components/confirm-button) which declares NgmConfirmButtonModule has not been processed correctly by ngcc, or is not compatible with Angular Ivy. Issues.Title: fix(ngcc): support ignoring deep-imports via package config
Issues.Body:
Recently we added support for ignoring specified deep-import
warnings by providing sets of regular expressions within the
`ngcc.config.js` file. But this was only working for the project
level configuration.

This commit fixes ngcc so that it will also read these regular
expressions from package level configuration too.

Fixes #35750
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ngcc): support ignoring deep-imports via package config" (#36423)

Issues.Title: fix(compiler): avoid generating i18n attributes in plain form
Issues.Body:
Prior to this change, there was a problem while matching template attributes, which mistakenly took i18n attributes (that might be present in attrs array after template ones) into account. This commit updates the logic to avoid template attribute matching logic from entering the i18n section and as a result this also allows generating proper i18n attributes sections instead of keeping these attribute in plain form (with their values) in attribute arrays.


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Bugfix


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler): avoid generating i18n attributes in plain form" (#36422)

Issues.Title: @angular/cdk/text-field NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of AppModule, but could not be resolved to an NgModule class.
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package `@angular/cdk/text-field` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: as far as I can see it worked in angular 8. But as we know the setup was different then as `cdk` was under `@angular/material`. ### Description Updating my project to angular 9 (from v6) caused the error: ``` ERROR in node_modules/@angular/cdk/text-field/autosize.d.ts:13:22 - error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of AppModule, but could not be resolved to an NgModule class. This likely means that the library (`@angular/cdk/text-field`) which declares CdkTextareaAutosize has not been processed correctly by ngcc, or is not compatible with Angular Ivy. Check if a newer version of the library is available, and update if so. Also consider checking with the library's authors to see if the library is expected to be compatible with Ivy. ``` when building with aot. I have seen several of these issues raised on the forum here and tried every solution/workaround I have seen. The reason I am posting my own issue here is because I have not seen anyone else having problems with th `@angular/cdk` package. The `ngcc` postinstall script works fine with all other packages, including `@angular/material`. Disabling `aot` or ivy works, but without ivy, what is the point of updating to ng9? I would appreciate any input here. I am quite at a loss at this point. Thanks :) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction - new project with `ng new testRepo` - `npm i @angular/material@9.2.0` or `ng add @angular/material` - Add `import { cdkTextAreaAutosize } from '@angular/cdk/text-field';` - and ```ts @NgModule({ declarations: [ AppComponent ], imports: [ BrowserModule, AppRoutingModule, BrowserAnimationsModule, CdkTextareaAutosize ], // <---- this causes the error providers: [], bootstrap: [ AppComponent ] }) export class AppModule {} ``` https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-issue-repro2-ysgv8g?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.module.ts ## üî• Exception or Error 

ERROR in node_modules/@angular/cdk/text-field/autosize.d.ts:13:22 - error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of AppModule, but could not be resolved to an NgModule class.

This likely means that the library (`@angular/cdk/text-field`) which declares CdkTextareaAutosize has not been processed correctly by ngcc, or is not compatible with Angular Ivy. Check if a newer version of the library is available, and update if so. Also consider checking with the library's authors to see if the library is expected to be compatible with Ivy.

Issues.Title: fix(ngcc): detect non-emitted, non-imported TypeScript helpers
Issues.Body:
When TypeScript downlevels ES2015+ code to ES5, it uses some helpers functions to emulated some ES2015+ features, such as spread syntax. The TypeScript compiler can be configured to emit these helpers into the transpiled code (which is controlled by the `noEmitHelpers` option - false by default). It can also be configured to import these helpers from the `tslib` module (which is controlled by the `importHelpers` option - false by default).

While most of the time the helpers will be either emitted or imported, it is possible that one configures their app to neither emit nor import them. In that case, the helpers could, for example, be made available on the global object. This is what `@nativescript/angular` v9.0.0-next-2019-11-12-155500-01 does. See, for example, [common.js][1].

Ngcc must be able to detect and statically evaluate these helpers. Previously, it was only able to detect emitted or imported helpers.

This commit adds support for detecting these helpers if they are neither emitted nor imported . It does this by checking identifiers for which no declaration (either concrete or inline) can be found against a list of known TypeScript helper function names.

##
This is needed for angular/ngcc-validation#1029.

[1]: https://unpkg.com/browse/@nativescript/angular@9.0.0-next-2019-11-12-155500-01/common.js
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ngcc): detect non-emitted, non-imported TypeScript helpers" (#36418)

Issues.Title: add casted control getters
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
`@angular/forms`

### Description
Currently `get` on AbstractControl returns an `AbstractControl`. This works as intended but dosen't play well with `strictTemplates` and deeply nested forms.

### Describe the solution you'd like
add the methosd `getGroup` `getControl` `getArray` which will run the `get` function but then cast the type and do a runtime check to ensure it's the correct runtime type also.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Put a method in your component class, but this isn't ergonomic
```
asControl(c: AbstractControl): FormControl { return c as FormControl }
```

Happy to submit a patch
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "add casted control getters" (#36405)

Issues.Title: add Promise<T> | Observable<T> async pipe overload
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
`@angular/common`

### Description
Currently the async pipe can take a Promise or Observable, but only as seperate obverloads, so with `strictTemplates` you get an error if you pass in a `Promise<T> | Observable<T>`

### Describe the solution you'd like
Add an overload which looks like `transform<T>(obj: Promise<T> | Observable<T> | null | undefined): T | null;`


### Describe alternatives you've considered
converting the promise into a observable, but this isn't ergonomic


Happy to submit a patch
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "add Promise<T> | Observable<T> async pipe overload" (#36404)

Issues.Title: Inline CSS from Angular Animations lost when reattaching Route Snapshot
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
@angular/animations
@angular/router

### Is this a regression?
Behavior started with angular 9

### Description
When using a Custom Route Reuse strategy the css that had been applied via an angular animation disappears leaving the element in neither "animation state"


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
https://github.com/IanNMarshall/angular9-animations-example

#### Steps to reproduce

1. Click the "animation" button to be routed to /animation

3. Click home to navigate away
4. Click "animation" again and the animation css has been removed, it is in neither the open or closed state.
5. Additionally if you now toggle the animation it works for all future routing

#### Working example
Same src as above example but pre angular 9, works as expected, keeps animation state.
https://github.com/IanNMarshall/angular8-animation-example

Issues.Title: `class` property not applied to component when Ivy is enabled
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
I'm not sure

### Is this a regression?
Yes, because Ivy was not present in previous versions

### Description
I'm the main author of an Angular library named `angular-archwizard`.
A few users of the library stumbled over the issue where the newest version of wizard, which has been built using Angular 9, does not seem to work when used in another project using Angular 9 and Ivy deactivated. 

### Ivy off
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18488086/78283547-38c31880-751e-11ea-8efa-453afb4bbd21.png)

### Ivy on
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18488086/78283613-53958d00-751e-11ea-9640-515ba62d0d0f.png)

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular9-archwizard-css?file=tsconfig.json

Flip `enableIvy` to `false` to see that the css classes are not applied anymore

## üî• Exception or Error
```
WARNING: sanitizing unsafe style value [object Object] (see http://g.co/ng/security#xss).
```

In addition it seems like the `class` property of the `aw-wizard-navigation-bar` is not applied correctly. Instead of `horizontal small` it contains `[object Object]` (see also https://github.com/madoar/angular-archwizard/issues/278#issuecomment-607490550).

Maybe the warning and the `class` property issue are connected?

## üåç  Your Environment
Link to the repository hosting `angular-archwizard`: https://github.com/madoar/angular-archwizard

**Anything else relevant?**
I'm not sure whether this is actually a bug in Angular or maybe a misconfiguration of `angular-archwizard`. Independent of this I think it is strange that also the tests of `angular-archwizard` only seem to work with Ivy enabled. If you disable it by adding 

```json
"angularCompilerOptions": {
  "enableIvy": false
}
```

to for example [`tsconfig`](https://github.com/madoar/angular-archwizard/blob/develop/tsconfig.json) a number of tests of `angular-archwizard` are failing as can be seen [here](https://github.com/madoar/angular-archwizard/runs/555130754).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`class` property not applied to component when Ivy is enabled" (#36400)

Issues.Title: fix(core): log error instead of warning for unknown properties and elements
Issues.Body:
**Note:** this is a resubmit of #35798 intended for v10.

Changes the Ivy unknown element/property messages from being logged with `console.warn` to `console.error`. This should make them a bit more visible without breaking existing apps. Furthermore, a lot of folks filter out warning messages in the dev tools' console, whereas errors are usually still shown.

BREAKING CHANGE:
Warnings about unknown elements are now logged as errors. This won't break your app, but it may trip up tools that expect nothing to be logged via `console.error`.

Fixes #35699.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(core): log error instead of warning for unknown properties and elements" (#36399)

# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [ ] new
- [X] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
Currently the anyComponentStyle budget applies to all components.  However we have a couple of components that significantly exceed the budget.  We'd like to make an exception for those components, but still get warnings/errors if other components go over budget.

### Describe the solution you'd like
A way to either specify an exception list to the anyComponentStyle budget, or a way to set a per component budget that would override the anyComponentStyle budget for the specified component.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
We've upped our budget, but the components in question are considerably larger than our average, so the budget is now pretty much useless.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Need a way to selectively disable component size budgets" (#17390)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/pwa): add purpose any to manifest icons
Issues.Body:
The `purpose` property defines the purpose of an icon, for example if the icon is intended to serve some special purpose in the context of the host OS (i.e., for better integration).

`Purpose` can have one or more of the following values, separated by spaces:

- `badge`: A user agent can present this icon where space constraints and/or color requirements differ from those of the application icon.
- `maskable`: The image is designed with icon masks and safe zone in mind, such that any part of the image outside the safe zone can safely be ignored and masked away by the user agent.
- `any`: The user agent is free to display the icon in any context (this is the default value).

Closes #17384
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular/pwa): add purpose any to manifest icons" (#17386)

Issues.Title: Since angular 9 webpack hooks can no longer indicate the end of localized build process
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: Angular v8 ### Description When building angular application using new `--localize` flag, the build process consists of two phases. First one is the webpack compilation and second is the post processing. Because of that after first phase output files land in `/tmp` directory instead of target destination. The problem is, that I've been using a `sentry` plugin that relies on webpack hook - `afterEmit`. Previously that hook allowed the plugin to read target (ex. `dist`) directory and access emitted files. Right now at the time when hook is executed `dist` directory remains empty until post-processing is completed. Of course I could (and I will) write custom node script that will be executed manually (or as a combined npm script) just after `ng build`. Are there plans to put that post processing back to webpack compilation process, or it's going to stay this way? ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Let me know if you need a reproduction. It's more conceptual issue ## üåç Your Environment 
Angular CLI: 9.1.0
Node: 10.16.0
OS: linux x64
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Since angular 9 webpack hooks can no longer indicate the end of localized build process" (#17381)

Issues.Title: ng build --prod changes opacity value of CSS rule on brand new ng new project
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)

- [ ] new
- [X] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc


### Is this a regression?

I don't know.

### Description

When doing ng build --prod, it changes the opacity value of a css rule.


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

Create a new project:

PS D:\Projects\Test Projects> ng new cssBug
? Would you like to add Angular routing? No
? Which stylesheet format would you like to use? SCSS   [ https://sass-lang.com/documentation/syntax#scss

Open file /src/styles.scss

Add the following lines in the file:

```
.mat-form-field-appearance-outline.mat-focused .mat-form-field-outline-thick, 
.mat-form-field-appearance-outline.mat-form-field-invalid.mat-form-field-invalid .mat-form-field-outline-thick {
  opacity: 50% !important;
}
```

Build new project:

PS D:\Projects\Test Projects> cd cssBug
PS D:\Projects\Test Projects\cssBug> ng build --prod

Open /dist/cssBug/style.hash.css.

Look at previously inserted lines. 

Result: opacity has been change from 50% !important to 1% !important.
I have reproduced this 3 times.

## üî• Exception or Error

No Exception. The error is a change in the CSS value of opacity.

## üåç Your Environment

PS D:\Projects\Test Projects\cssBug> ng version

Angular CLI: 9.1.0
Node: 10.16.3
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 9.1.0
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.901.0
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.901.0
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.901.0
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.901.0
@angular-devkit/core              9.1.0
@angular-devkit/schematics        9.1.0
@ngtools/webpack                  9.1.0
@schematics/angular               9.1.0
@schematics/update                0.901.0
rxjs                              6.5.4
typescript                        3.8.3
webpack                           4.42.0

**Anything else relevant?**

Change in CSS rule causes a display issue when going from dev to prod build. Issue is visible across all browsers.

Issues.Title: XRegExp pattern fails when using IE11 (polyfills-es5)
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/core ### Is this a regression? Yes - works fine on 8.x ### Description ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Create a fresh project (Angular 9.1) and replace main.ts with the following content: https://gist.github.com/psmyrdek/a32ed781830f1c69472c0580123330ef It works on Chrome, Firefox, etc. but it doesn't work on IE11. Everything is fine if we're on 8.x ## üî• Exception or Error ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6187417/78266758-7d42ba00-7506-11ea-8a9e-97fac8e63160.png) ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 9.1.0

Issues.Body:
I am using `front end maven plugin` to run unit tests in Angular.
Angular 6 version is being used 
 
Below is the configuration - 

**karma.conf.js :**

    module.exports = function (config) {
      config.set({
        basePath: '',
        frameworks: ['jasmine', '@angular-devkit/build-angular'],
        plugins: [
          require('karma-jasmine'),
          require('karma-chrome-launcher'),
          require('karma-jasmine-html-reporter'),
          require('karma-coverage-istanbul-reporter'),
          require('@angular-devkit/build-angular/plugins/karma')
        ],
        client: {
          clearContext: false browser
        },
        coverageIstanbulReporter: {
          dir: require('path').join(__dirname, '../../coverage'), 
          reports: [ 'html', 'lcovonly', 'text-summary' ],
          fixWebpackSourcePaths: true
        },
        angularCli: {
          environment: 'dev'
        },
        reporters: ['progress', 'kjhtml'],
        port: 9876,
        colors: true,
        logLevel: config.LOG_INFO,
        autoWatch: true,
        browsers: ['Chrome'],
        singleRun: false,
        restartOnFileChange: true,
    	browserNoActivityTimeout: 100000
      });
    };

**pom.xml :** 

    <execution>
    	<id>test</id>
    	<goals>
    			<goal>karma</goal>

    	<phase>test</phase>
    	<configuration>
    		<karmaConfPath>karma.conf.js</karmaConfPath>
    		<arguments>--code-coverage</arguments>
    	</configuration>
    </execution>


I am getting below error when I run - `mvn clean install` 

Server start failed on port 9876: Error: The `'@angular-devkit/build-angular/plugins/karma'` karma plugin is meant to be used from within Angular CLI and will not work correctly outside of it.

I have researched a bit and found below links but I havent yet found any solution. 
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/10703#issuecomment-387319138

Please not that we have to do **this from maven only** 

Can anybody please help here as I am struggling to get this running ?

Issues.Title: improve testing capabilities
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request
I see that tremendous advancements were already made in the last years, dear Angular Team: Thank you for that!

There is something that I'd like to start a discussion on:

Faster and specific tests.

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
- [ x] test

### Description
Looking at just and wallaby.js I really would like to have that by default in Angular when running ng test (in watch mode). 

As I like to keep my applications in standard, I think we all could benefit from improvements like these.

### Describe the solution you'd like
I think the main features are:
- if you change a test, just rerun that specific test
- if you change code, determine which tests are affected and rerun these tests
- if you change code in a spec file other than a specific test, rerun the whole spec
- have a state of tests in memory and show interesting information about it in vs code

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Aquire wallaby.js and integrate it.

Input welcome.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "improve testing capabilities" (#17368)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-optimizer): use TypeScript 3.6
Issues.Body:
When used within the build optimizer, TypeScript 3.8 will consider certain imports to be unreferenced and errantly remove them even though they are used within the module.  This results in runtime errors during application load.  TypeScript 3.7 cannot be used due to it causing a build time error when used within the build optimizer.  The build optimizer uses an independent version of TypeScript which allows it to use TypeScript 3.6 while applications continue to use TypeScript 3.7 or 3.8 to build the actual application.

Fixes: #17320
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-optimizer): use TypeScript 3.6" (#17364)

Issues.Title: docs-bug(datepicker): matDatepickerFilter API documentation has incorrect type
Issues.Body:
#### Documentation Feedback

The API documentation for matDatepickerFilter shows it's type as  `(date: D) => boolean` when it's actually  `(date: D | null) => boolean`.  

It also doesn't explain what conditions would cause it to get called with a null value.  

I noticed the example on the Examples tab does have the correct type, but just does a (d || new Date()) and gives no reason for why null should be treated as the current datetime.

**Affected documentation page:** Insert a link to the affected page on material.angular.io

https://material.angular.io/components/datepicker/api#MatDatepickerInput
https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/datepicker/datepicker-input.ts#L118

Issues.Title: bug(dialog): JSONEditor inputs not working in material dialog
Issues.Body:
#### Expected Behavior Angular Material dialog with a JSONEditor (https://github.com/josdejong/jsoneditor) object embedded in it would allow editing of text fields in the JSON editor. #### Actual Behavior Angular Material dialog with a JSONEditor object embedded in it no longer allows editing of text fields. Non-text fields work correctly. The JSONEditor object uses a contenteditable div as such: ```
my text
``` rather than an HTML input field. Keyboard input currently is ignored and dragging to select text instead drags the dialog around the window. The JSONEditor object's search field, which is an HTML text input, functions as expected so it's likely some interaction between Material and the contenteditable div that is the problem. #### Environment - Angular: 9.1.0 - CDK/Material: 9.2.0 - Browser(s): Chrome 80.0.3987.149 - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(dialog): JSONEditor inputs not working in material dialog" (#18984)

Issues.Body: When animations are disabled, the ripple elements sets the animation duration of its global options to zero. The problem is that it's mutating the object that's used by all other ripples. The issue can be observed by going to the MDC checkbox demo and then trying to interact with something that should have a ripple.

Issues.Title: bug([moment-date-adapter]): MomentDateAdapter not guarding against `undefined` locale
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Using the `MomentDateAdapter` and setting up the locale as `undefined` leads to an error. Calling `this._adapter.setLocale(undefined)` is not throwing an exception. When the `MomentDateAdapter` calls `createDate()`, it specifically calls:

`const result = this._createMoment({year, month, date}).locale(this.locale);`

Since `this.locale` is `undefined`, the `locale()` method of moment acts as a getter, thus returning a default locale such as `en`.

The `MomentDateAdapter` further checks for

`if (!result.isValid())`

which is failing, because the method `.isValid()` does not exist for type `string`.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

`setLocale()` should guard against an `undefined` value, or the `createDate()` method should deal with this unexpected behavior more gracefully.

#### Actual Behavior

`MomentDateAdapter` initialization fails with `ERROR TypeError: result.isValid is not a function`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug([moment-date-adapter]): MomentDateAdapter not guarding against `undefined` locale " (#18971)

Issues.Title: bug([datepicker]): Custom DatepickerIntl don't work in lazy loaded modules
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction
I created here MyIntl class and I set there only text for calendar open button.
https://angular-material-datepicker-intl.stackblitz.io

Steps to reproduce:
1. If you check first calendar button it has aria-label="test" so it works. It works also for second calendar that is in first lazy loadad module
2. But if you click link 'lazy-loaded' and check button for 'other lazy' calendar it's aria-label is default 'Open calendar'

Issues.Body:
Fixes the `disableClose` option not working for template-based dialogs, because we have two separate places where the config was being synced up with the dialog ref and one of them wasn't updated. These changes move the creation logic to a single place.

Fixes #18964.

Issues.Title: fix(google-maps): not rendering until mapTypeId is set
Issues.Body:
In 2a6aae179a436886395cc8ecc631f7c7be4dff24 I added the ability to set the `mapTypeId` and after I was done with it and ran the unit tests, I added a default of `undefined` to the `DEFAULT_OPTIONS` so the tests didn't have to be updated. It looks like having the `undefined` in the defaults causes Google Maps not to render anything in the map until the map type changes. These changes remove the default value and update the tests instead.

Fixes #18965.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(google-maps): not rendering until mapTypeId is set" (#18967)

Issues.Title: bug([google-map]): [README.MD example only produces grey rectangle, no map]
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

The README for Google Maps contains code that produces just a grey map:
https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/google-maps/README.md

Steps to reproduce:
 Add the readme code to a brand new simple new demo project (ng new demo)  
 
#### Expected Behavior
The map should be displayed correctly, without having to force a refresh. 

#### Actual Behavior
A grey rectangle is displayed where the map should be. 
No error messages are produced. 
Note the README example did work correctly for Google Maps in Angular Components 9.0. 

With Google-Maps in Angular Components 9.2, to get a map correctly displayed, one now needs to add this extra line to the demo .html file:
            [mapTypeId]="mapTypeId"
And add this line to the demo .ts file:
mapTypeId: google.maps.MapTypeId;
and also implement AfterViewInit to force a redraw:
export class GoogleMapDemo implements AfterViewInit {
..
ngAfterViewInit(): void {
// Vary the map properties somehow to force a redraw
    this.mapTypeId = google.maps.MapTypeId.ROADMAP;
  }
}

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.1.0
- CDK/Material: 9.2.0
- Browser(s): Chrome 83.0.4093.3
- Operating System: Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug([google-map]): [README.MD example only produces grey rectangle, no map]" (#18965)

Issues.Title: bug(cdk-experimental:DIALOG): Config option disableClose does not work with openFromTemplate
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

While using the dialog to open a template by calling `openFromTemplate`, the `disableClose` is not respected. When you use a component by calling `openFromComponent`, the `disableClose` does work.

Most likely cause:

Inside [`_attachDialogContentForComponent`](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/8a712884701e05c88dfc4358c3f3ffc44c42f6d3/src/cdk-experimental/dialog/dialog.ts#L235) there is a 
```
dialogRef.disableClose = config.disableClose;
```

This is missing in the [` _attachDialogContentForTemplate`](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/8a712884701e05c88dfc4358c3f3ffc44c42f6d3/src/cdk-experimental/dialog/dialog.ts#L252)

#### Expected Behavior

That the dialog doesn't close on Escape key if `disableClose` is true

#### Actual Behavior

It closes when it shouldn't :(

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.1.0
- CDK-experimental: 9.2.0
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(cdk-experimental:DIALOG): Config option disableClose does not work with openFromTemplate" (#18964)

Issues.Title: Enable tree-shaking of more services
Issues.Body:
This branch is an attempt to improve tree-shaking of several services.

I started by removing the services that are `providedIn: 'root'` from the `providers` of any module, as that should not be needed and actually prevents them from being removed by tree-shaking.

I am investigating whether the remaining services (such as `MatDialog` and `Overlay`) need to be provided explicitly or if they can also become tree-shakable.

This branch aims at fixing https://github.com/angular/components/issues/11581 and https://github.com/angular/components/issues/18944
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Enable tree-shaking of more services" (#18962)
